title: Bielsko
text:
Bielsko (, ) was until 1950 an independent town situated in <a href="Cieszyn%20Silesia">Cieszyn Silesia</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>. In 1951 it was joined with <a href="Bia%C5%82a%20Krakowska">Biała Krakowska</a> to form the new town of <a href="Bielsko-Bia%C5%82a">Bielsko-Biała</a>. Bielsko constitutes the western part of that town.
Bielsko was founded by the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Cieszyn">Cieszyn Piast dukes</a> in the late 13th century on the grounds of village later called <a href="Stare%20Bielsko">Stare Bielsko</a> ("Old Bielsko"), on the <a href="Bia%C5%82a%20River%20%28Vistula%20basin%29">Biała River</a>. It was first mentioned in a written document in 1312. Originally settled by Germans, it became the largest German-language center ("Deutsche Sprachinsel Bielitz") in the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Teschen">Duchy of Teschen</a>, and remained so until the end of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. In 1572 it gained autonomy as the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Bielsko">Duchy (State) of Bielsko</a>. During the 18th century a rapid development of <a href="textile">textile</a> industry occurred, and at the beginning of the 19th century more than 500 <a href="weaving">weaver</a>s worked in the town. After the 1920 division of <a href="Cieszyn%20Silesia">Cieszyn Silesia</a> between <a href="Poland">Poland</a> and <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> it became, despite the protests of local Germans, a part of Poland.
According to the <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austrian</a> census of 1910 the town had 18,568 inhabitants. The census asked people for their native language: 15,144 (84.3%) were German-speaking, 2,568 (14.3%) were Polish-speaking and 136 (0.7%) were Czech-speaking. <a href="Jews">Jews</a> were not allowed to declare <a href="Yiddish%20language">Yiddish</a>, and most of them thus declared German as their native language. The most populous religious groups were <a href="Roman%20Catholics">Roman Catholics</a> with 10,378 (55.9%), followed by <a href="Protestants">Protestants</a> with 4,955 (26.7%) and the <a href="Jews">Jews</a> with 3,024 (16.3%). The vast majority of the Jews were exterminated by Nazis during World War II, and the German population was expelled by the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviets</a> after the war under the terms demanded by Stalin at the <a href="Potsdam%20Conference">Potsdam Conference</a>.
Three well-known <a href="Holocaust%20survivors">Holocaust survivors</a> from Bielsko are <a href="Kitty%20Hart-Moxon">Kitty Hart-Moxon</a>, <a href="Roman%20Frister">Roman Frister</a> and <a href="Gerda%20Weissmann%20Klein">Gerda Weissmann Klein</a>. All three have written autobiographies and other works about their experiences during the Second World War. The ancestors of the British peer <a href="Christopher%20Tugendhat%2C%20Baron%20Tugendhat">Christopher Tugendhat, Baron Tugendhat</a>, are also from what was Bielitz.
